name: Kepler-272
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-272 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-272 is a star with 0.845 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.93 times its radius. It is located 2977.32 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-272 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-272 b

Kepler-272 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.97 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-272.

The mass of Kepler-272 b is 2.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-272 b is 1.43 that of Earth. At 2.29 Earth masses, Kepler-272 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-272 c

Kepler-272 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-272.

The mass of Kepler-272 c is 3.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-272 c is 1.79 that of Earth. At 3.91 Earth masses, Kepler-272 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-272 d

Kepler-272 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.94 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-272.

The mass of Kepler-272 d is 6.76 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-272 d is 2.25 that of Earth. At 6.76 Earth masses, Kepler-272 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-272, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
